energy law.title: 1.2: The First Law of Thermodynamics - Chemistry LibreTexts
energy law.processed_content:
The first law states that the change in energy (\(\Delta U\)) of a system is equal to the sum of the work done on the system (\(w\)) and heat (\(q\)) put into the system. We see from Equation \ref{EQ:firstlaw} that the first law of thermodynamics is a statement about the conservation of energy. In order for the energy of the system to change, energy must be transferred to/from the surroundings in the form of either heat or work.

The primary energy law discussed is the First Law of Thermodynamics, which asserts the conservation of energy. It states that any change in a system's internal energy results from the exchange of heat or work with its surroundings. This principle is mathematically expressed as the change in internal energy equaling the sum of heat added to the system and work done on the system.

English is unusual in having such a large proportion of its users as second or foreign language speakers.

epidemiology.title: Epidemiology | Disease Transmission, Risk Factors & Prevention | Britannica

ethnic studies.title: Ethnic studies
ethnic studies.processed_content: Ethnic studies is an interdisciplinary academic field that emerged in the United States to critically examine race, ethnicity, and power dynamics, often focusing on the histories and experiences of people of color. It developed partly in response to perceived Eurocentric biases in traditional disciplines and aims to re-frame narratives from the perspectives of marginalized groups. The field utilizes intersectional approaches to understand how categories like race, gender, class, and sexuality interact, and it encompasses various subfields dedicated to specific ethnic groups.

The field seeks to provide insight into issues of race and ethnicity, aiming to enhance cultural competency, equity skills, and civic engagement.

ethnic studies.title: Ethnic Studies: Meaning & Importance - Anthropology

Drawing insights from various disciplines, the field analyzes gender dynamics and power structures to promote understanding, equality, and social justice.

Specialists in this area, known as geriatricians, manage care often through an interdisciplinary team to ensure comprehensive support for older patients.

geriatrics.title: Everything You Need to Know About Geriatrics

This field is distinct from gerontology, which focuses on the study of the aging process itself.

gerontology.title: What is Gerontology? The Study of Aging | SNHU
gerontology.processed_content: Gerontology is the scientific study of aging and the aging process, focusing on physical, mental, social, and societal implications. global health.title: The Importance of Global Engagement in the Public Health Sector

health policy.title: Home - Public Health Policy - UWM Libraries
health policy.processed_content: Health policy encompasses the laws, regulations, actions, and decisions implemented within society with the aim of promoting wellness and achieving specific health goals. health promotion.title: Health promotion
health promotion.processed_content: Health promotion is defined as the process of enabling people to increase control over and improve their health. This approach extends beyond individual behavior change and health education to encompass broader social and environmental interventions that address the determinants of health. It involves coordinated action across various sectors and public policies to create supportive conditions and advance health equity.

health promotion.title: Health Promotion

It aims to strengthen individuals' and communities' capacities while also modifying social, environmental, and economic conditions to create healthier settings. This approach requires participatory, intersectoral action across multiple levels to empower people and address the social determinants of health. It extends beyond clinical services to encompass a whole-of-government and society-wide effort.

health promotion.title: What is Health promotion - Meaning and definition - Pallipedia
health promotion.processed_content: Health promotion is the process of enabling people to increase control over their health. It focuses on well-being and disease prevention. The first major health promotion conference was held in Ottawa in 1986.

human rights.processed_content: Human rights in law are universal protections for fundamental freedoms and dignity, enshrined in international treaties and national laws. immunology.title: Outline of immunology - Wikipedia

immunology.title: Common Immunology Specializations and Fields
immunology.processed_content: Immunology is the scientific study of the immune system and its functions, focusing on how the body defends itself against pathogens. immunology.title: Immune system - Wikipedia

infectious disease.title: Infection - Wikipedia
infectious disease.processed_content: An infectious disease is caused by pathogens like bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. They spread through contact, contaminated food/water, or vectors. Vaccines and treatments exist for many, but some remain difficult to manage.

infectious disease.title: Infectious Disease: Types, Symptoms, Causes and Treatment
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are illnesses caused by pathogens such as viruses, bacteria, fungi, or parasites. Characterized by their ability to spread rapidly through communities, they represent a significant public health concern.

infectious disease.title: List of infectious diseases - Wikipedia
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are conditions caused by specific infectious agents. The text indicates these causative agents are diverse, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, helminths, and prions. These diseases are typically associated with defined diagnostic methods, treatments, and sometimes preventive vaccines.

infectious disease.title: Infectious Disease | Germs | MedlinePlus
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are illnesses caused by germs, which are microbes found in various environments that have the capacity to make a person sick.

infectious disease.title: Infectious Diseases - Rhode Island Department of Health
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are illnesses caused by microscopic organisms like bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. These agents live in people, animals, or the environment and can spread through various means, including person-to-person contact or exposure to contaminated sources.

infectious disease.title: About the National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic ...
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are illnesses caused by germs that invade and multiply within the body, resulting in an infection. These conditions can be triggered by various microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

infectious disease.title: Glossary | NERD Academy | CDC
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases are health conditions resulting from the presence of infectious agents. These agents are organisms, such as viruses, bacteria, fungi, or parasites, that invade and grow within a susceptible host, causing sickness or illness.

infectious disease.title: Climate change and infectious diseases - Wikipedia
infectious disease.processed_content: Infectious diseases, also known as pathogenic diseases, result from a pathogen coming into contact with a person. These diseases can be transmitted through various means, including vectors like mosquitoes and ticks, as well as through contaminated water or food. The occurrence of such diseases depends on factors like the pathogen's strength and the individual's resistance.

information engineering.title: Information theory - Wikipedia

instruction.title: INSTRUCTION Definition & Meaning

This systematic method incorporates principles like reinforcement and feedback to ensure effective learning and skill acquisition.

instruction.title: INSTRUCTION Definition & Meaning

Different instruction sets, like ARM, Thumb, and AArch64, vary in characteristics such as bit encoding (e.g., 16-bit, 32-bit, 64-bit) and functionality, catering to different roles and performance needs. These instructions encompass operations like arithmetic, data processing, memory access, and specialized functions.

It also encompasses language that makes presumptions about the reader's knowledge, such as "of course" or "obviously". This type of instructional or presumptuous language is considered unencyclopedic and should be avoided in favor of presenting sourced facts neutrally.

instruction.title: Phonics - Wikipedia
instruction.processed_content: Instruction, within the context of the text, refers to the deliberate methods and processes employed to teach foundational academic skills, particularly reading. These intellectual and religious developments have shaped diverse approaches within Judaism.

This synthesis led to diverse approaches, reconciling religious teachings with philosophical reasoning and contributing a cornerstone to Jewish scholarship.

This legal framework regulates various workplace conditions such as wages, working hours, health and safety, and protection against discrimination.

labor law.title: Employment discrimination law in the United States - Wikipedia

These laws primarily prohibit discrimination in employment practices like hiring, promotion, and compensation based on protected characteristics such as race, sex, age, and disability. While the U.S. Constitution limits government discrimination, a significant body of statutory law governs both public and private sector employment to ensure equal opportunity. State laws often provide protections for additional categories or apply to employers not covered by federal statutes.

It involves the planning, implementation, and control of the physical flow of materials and the associated information flow from point of origin to point of consumption.

Logistics involves the systematic planning, implementation, and control of the efficient physical flow of materials, products, and related information from their point of origin to the point of consumption. It encompasses the management of activities such as acquisition, storage, and transportation to ensure resources and goods reach their final destination effectively. This process is a vital component of business operations and integral to managing supply chains.

romance languages.title: Palatalization in the Romance languages - Wikipedia
romance languages.processed_content: Romance languages constitute a family of languages descended from Latin, specifically Vulgar Latin spoken in the Roman Empire. These changes led to the development of new consonants and phonetic features, resulting in the distinct forms of modern Romance languages like Italian, Spanish, French, and Portuguese.

romance languages.title: Your Guide to Romance Languages - Rosetta Stone
romance languages.processed_content: Romance languages originated from Vulgar Latin, the conversational form of Latin spoken throughout the Roman Empire. Belonging to the Indo-European language family, they share common grammatical structures and vocabulary due to their Latin ancestry.

romance languages.title: What are Romance Languages and Where Are They Spoken? - Lingopie
romance languages.processed_content: Romance languages are modern languages that evolved from Vulgar Latin, the everyday speech of common people during the Roman Empire. romance languages.title: Understanding Romance Languages: Origins, Influence, and Global Reach
romance languages.processed_content: Romance languages are a family of languages whose name derives from the Latin word "Romanicus," reflecting their origin in the Roman Empire. These languages, such as French, Spanish, and Italian, share this common root in Vulgar Latin.

romance literatures.processed_content: The term "romance" in literature originally designated popular narrative fiction, particularly chivalric tales of adventure and honor written in vernacular languages. This body of work, focusing on subjective experience and imagination, forms a significant part of literary history associated with the term.

romance literatures.title: Measuring readers of romance | Penn Today
romance literatures.processed_content: Romance literature is identified as a uniquely large, complex, and dynamic genre within the contemporary literary system. This intricate genre ecosystem is considered worthy of serious academic study due to its complexity and significance.

school psychology.title: Role of Educational Psychology in Teaching and Learning

science teaching.processed_content: Science teaching, as described in this text, emphasizes fostering curiosity and critical thinking through practical, hands-on learning experiences, particularly within laboratories. secondary education.title: What Do Primary, Secondary, and Post ...
secondary education.processed_content: Secondary education is the formal schooling stage that follows primary education, typically divided into lower and upper sections. Lower secondary education, often called middle school, generally occurs between ages 11 and 14, while upper secondary education, or high school, usually covers ages 14 to 18. This stage serves as the transition before post-secondary or tertiary education.

secondary education.title: What does secondary school mean? - California Learning Resource Network
secondary education.processed_content: Secondary education is the formal stage of schooling that follows primary education, typically serving students from ages 11-13 through 16-18. This phase focuses on a curriculum of core and elective subjects aimed at preparing students for future academic pursuits and professional development.

secondary education.title: Higher Education vs Secondary Education: Core Differences
secondary education.processed_content: Secondary education, typically including middle and high school, provides students with a broad foundational knowledge across various subjects. It focuses on equipping students with essential skills and preparing them for either higher education or direct entry into the workforce. This stage is characterized by a structured learning environment with significant teacher guidance and monitored progress, aiming to develop fundamental academic and personal skills.

secondary education.title: Secondary education | Benefits, Challenges & Solutions | Britannica
secondary education.processed_content: Secondary education is the stage after primary education, typically ages 11 to 18. It includes high school and prepares students for higher education or vocational training. In many countries, it is compulsory until a certain age.

secondary education.title: Educational stage - Wikipedia

This stage generally serves children from around age five or six up to age ten, eleven, or twelve.

secondary education.title: Education in Australia - Wikipedia

Instead, some secondary schools are divided into junior, intermediate, and senior levels covering years often associated with middle grades. The Northern Territory is an exception, having established a three-tier system including middle schools for Years 7 to 9.

secondary education.title: Secondary School Vs. High School? Key Differences | UoPeople
secondary education.processed_content: Secondary education is the stage of schooling that occurs after primary or elementary school and before higher education, such as university or college. This level typically includes a period of compulsory attendance and is designed to prepare students for various post-graduation options, including further academic pursuits, vocational training, or entering the workforce. Although specific grades and names vary globally, secondary education serves as a foundational bridge to post-compulsory opportunities.

Key federal components include the Securities Act, which regulates the offering and sale of securities and requires registration unless an exemption applies, and the Exchange Act, which mandates regular reporting by public companies.

social foundations of education.title: Social Foundations of Education Reader
social foundations of education.processed_content: Social Foundations of Education critically examines the intricate relationships between educational systems and the broader social, cultural, economic, and political forces that shape them. social foundations of education.title: Social Foundations - Virginia Commonwealth University
social foundations of education.processed_content: Social foundations of education is an interdisciplinary field that examines how social, cultural, political, economic, and historical forces shape educational systems and practices. This study aims to understand and address issues of equity, access, and social justice within educational contexts.

social foundations of education.title: The Sociological Foundations of Curriculum: Bridging Society ...
social foundations of education.processed_content: The social foundations of education examine the profound connections between education and the social environment. social foundations of education.title: Theories of Historical and Social Foundations of Education
social foundations of education.processed_content: Social foundations of education involve understanding the historical and philosophical principles shaping educational systems within societal contexts. It also explores the educator's role in impacting culture and demonstrating social responsibility.

social health.title: Bringing Social Health to Healthcare: A Call to Action
social health.processed_content: Social health refers to the quality and quantity of our relationships and social connections, impacting both mental and physical well-being. social health.title: What is social health? The little-known idea that could ...
social health.processed_content: Social health is a vital dimension of overall wellbeing that stems from human connection and relationships. It involves cultivating bonds with family and friends, belonging to communities, and feeling supported, valued, and loved. Research demonstrates that social health is as essential as physical and mental health, significantly influencing longevity and susceptibility to diseases. Recognizing and prioritizing social health provides a positive framework for enhancing overall wellbeing through meaningful connections.

social work.title: Addressing Health-Related Social Needs: Why Social Work Matters in ...
social work.processed_content: Social work involves supporting individuals in vulnerable moments through compassion and action. In healthcare, social workers address non-medical factors impacting health, such as housing or food insecurity, by identifying challenges and connecting people to necessary resources. Their work aims to improve health outcomes and ensure individuals receive the care and support they need by addressing health-related social needs.

space engineering.title: Space Engineering | Texas A&M University Engineering
space engineering.processed_content: Space engineering is the discipline focused on developing the technologies and systems required for humanity to explore, inhabit, and operate in space and on other celestial bodies. It involves advancing areas such as space robotics, environmental systems for extreme conditions, and technologies essential for space travel, exploration, and future colonization efforts. This field provides the fundamental capabilities needed to enable human presence and activity beyond Earth.

space engineering.title: Aerospace Engineering: Complete Guide To Key Concepts
space engineering.processed_content: Astronautical engineering, a key branch of aerospace engineering, focuses on the design, development, and construction of spacecraft for operations beyond Earth's atmosphere. This field involves creating vehicles and systems for space travel, exploration, scientific research, and communication satellites. It requires expertise in navigating the vacuum of space and withstanding extreme cosmic environments.

space engineering.title: Spaceflight - Wikipedia

space engineering.title: What is Aerospace Engineering? - University of North Dakota

studio art.title: Studio Art: Techniques & Definition - StudySmarter

supply chain management.title: Supply chain management - Wikipedia
supply chain management.processed_content: Supply chain management oversees the flow of goods, information, and finances from raw materials to finished products. It aims to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance customer satisfaction. Key functions include planning, sourcing, production, distribution, and returns.

supply chain management.title: Importance of Supply Chain Management - Intellipaat
supply chain management.processed_content: Supply chain management oversees the flow of goods and information from suppliers to customers, ensuring efficient production and delivery. It optimizes processes to reduce costs and improve customer satisfaction. It includes sourcing, manufacturing, and logistics.

supply chain management.title: What Can You Do with a Supply Chain Management Degree?
supply chain management.processed_content: Supply chain management involves overseeing and coordinating the complex network of activities required to produce and deliver goods and services, from sourcing raw materials through manufacturing, distribution, and logistics, to reaching the final consumer. This process encompasses everything from product development and sourcing to production, transportation, and the information systems that connect these functions. Effective supply chain management aims to ensure the right products arrive at the right place and time efficiently and cost-effectively, impacting virtually all types of businesses.

systems engineering.title: Systems Engineering vs. Industrial Engineering | JHU EP

tax law.title: LibGuides: Federal Tax Research: Understanding Tax Law
tax law.processed_content: Tax law is the system of government-imposed laws, rules, policies, and regulations that govern the process of taxation on various items like income, property, and transactions. This field is inherently complex and constantly changes due to new legislation, court decisions, and administrative rulings. Its sources include statutes passed by Congress, regulations from agencies such as the IRS, and judicial case law.

tax law.title: Tax law - Wikiwand
tax law.processed_content: Tax law governs how governments collect revenue through taxes. It includes various types like income, estate, and sales taxes. Tax law is part of public law and is studied by accountants, lawyers, and tax agents.

tax law.title: What Are Tax Laws? - TurboTax Tax Tips & Videos - Intuit
tax law.processed_content: Tax law comprises the legal rules and procedures established by federal, state, and local governments to calculate taxes owed across various types, such as income, property, and corporate taxes. Federal tax law is based on the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) and further interpreted by Treasury regulations. Tax laws are not static and can change frequently.

tax law.title: Tax Law in Business: Navigating the Key Concepts
tax law.processed_content: Tax law comprises the government's rules, policies, and regulations governing the collection, management, and enforcement of taxes at federal, state, and international levels. This legal framework is integral to a country's economic structure, affecting both individuals and businesses. It dictates how taxes are calculated, filed, and paid, encompassing areas like income tax, corporate tax, and international tax.

tax law.title: United States Tax Court - Wikipedia
tax law.processed_content: Based on the text about the United States Tax Court, tax law in the US primarily concerns federal taxation, including income tax, and is codified in the Internal Revenue Code. This body of law is subject to interpretation and dispute, often requiring resolution in specialized courts like the Tax Court to ensure consistent application.

tax law.title: Income tax in the United States - Wikipedia
tax law.processed_content: United States tax law comprises statutes, regulations, and court decisions that govern the imposition and collection of taxes at the federal, state, and local levels, primarily focusing on income tax. This body of law defines taxable income, specifies allowable deductions and credits, and sets tax rates for various entities such as individuals and corporations. It dictates the process for calculating, reporting, and paying taxes, often serving as a tool for public policy in addition to revenue generation.

teacher education.title: Teacher education
teacher education.processed_content: Teacher education refers to the comprehensive programs and processes intended to prepare prospective teachers for their roles and support the ongoing development of current educators. These initiatives aim to equip teachers with the necessary knowledge, skills, attitudes, and methodologies for effective practice in the classroom, school, and community. It typically includes both initial training before beginning teaching and continuous professional learning throughout one's career.

teacher education.title: Special education - Wikipedia
teacher education.processed_content: Exceptional student education, also known as special education, is the practice of adapting teaching methods, materials, and settings to accommodate the individual differences, disabilities, and special needs of students. This field involves providing planned and monitored interventions, such as tailored teaching procedures and adapted equipment, to help students with diverse needs achieve greater self-sufficiency and academic success than they might in a standard classroom environment. It aims to support students with a wide range of challenges, including learning disabilities, communication disorders, physical disabilities, and developmental disabilities.

teacher education.title: History of education in the United States - Wikipedia
teacher education.processed_content: Elementary education in the United States, historically known as primary schooling, began with basic literacy and arithmetic instruction delivered through families or early community schools. This foundational level evolved into publicly supported common schools, becoming tax-subsidized nationwide by 1870. Initially characterized by multi-aged one-room schoolhouses, elementary education transitioned towards age-graded systems and received significant federal support through legislation like the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.

technical education.title: Technical Education: Importance, components, contexts
technical education.processed_content: Technical education provides practical skills and knowledge for specific trades, preparing individuals for skilled jobs through hands-on training and theoretical learning. technical education.title: Vocational education

This type of education is delivered through various institutions and levels, preparing people for skilled crafts and technical roles across different sectors.

technical education.title: Institute of technology - Wikipedia
technical education.processed_content: Technical education involves specialized training in applied sciences, engineering, technology, and vocational skills. Offered by institutions like polytechnics and technical institutes, it often emphasizes practical application and professional readiness for specific trades or technical roles. The level and qualifications provided, ranging from diplomas to degrees, vary across different educational systems globally.

technical education.title: Government of India, All India Council for Technical Education
technical education.processed_content: Technical education, as defined by the AICTE act, encompasses programs involving education, research, and training. These programs cover specific fields such as Engineering, Technology, Architecture, Town Planning, Management, Pharmacy, and Applied Arts and Crafts. It also includes other areas officially designated by the Central Government in consultation with the Council.

technical education.title: Educational technology - Wikipedia
technical education.processed_content: Instructional technology encompasses the theory and practice involved in designing, developing, utilizing, managing, and evaluating processes and resources to facilitate learning. It represents a systematic approach focused on the methods and tools used to enhance educational outcomes.

textile chemistry.title: What is Textile Engineering? at Engineers Heaven Q & A
textile chemistry.processed_content: Textile chemistry is the study of chemicals used in textile processing, including dyes, finishes, and treatments to enhance fabric properties. textile chemistry.title: Cotton - Wikipedia
textile chemistry.processed_content: Textile chemistry, as it pertains to cotton, involves understanding the fiber's primary composition of cellulose and its chemical properties like resistance to various substances and reactions to heat. This field encompasses processing techniques such as dyeing and mercerization, along with the application of agricultural chemicals like fertilizers, insecticides, and herbicides during cultivation. It also includes exploring chemical modifications through genetic engineering and utilizing cotton byproducts in chemical manufacturing processes.

textile engineering.title: What is Textile Engineering? at Engineers Heaven Q & A
textile engineering.processed_content: Textile engineering is a branch of engineering focused on the design, production, and manufacturing of fibers, textiles, and related products. It applies engineering principles to the textile industry, encompassing areas like fiber science, yarn and fabric production, dyeing, finishing, and quality control. This field integrates knowledge from materials science and chemistry to create functional and aesthetic textiles for diverse applications such as clothing, home furnishings, and technical uses.

textile engineering.title: Textile Engineering: Definition & Principles
textile engineering.processed_content: Textile engineering is an interdisciplinary field that applies scientific and engineering principles to the design, production, and control of textile materials, processes, and machinery. textile engineering.title: Textile Engineering: Definition & Principles | Vaia

theatre.title: Theater | EBSCO Research Starters

theatre.processed_content: Theatre is an ancient and evolving human cultural practice that utilizes performance to tell stories and explore the human condition. Fundamentally, theatre centers on human connection, bringing people together to share a collective story and experience.

theatre.title: Theatre of Australia - Wikipedia

theatre.title: Theatre | History, Performance, & Impact | Britannica

transplantation surgery.title: Organ transplantation

transplantation surgery.processed_content: Transplantation surgery is a medical procedure where a damaged or failing organ or tissue is replaced with a healthy one from a donor. transplantation surgery.title: Liver Transplant: Criteria, Surgery & Recovery, Life After

This surgery serves as a lifesaving treatment for conditions like organ failure or certain cancers. It involves surgically removing the diseased organ and implanting the donor organ to restore vital bodily functions.

transplantation surgery.title: Transplant | Definition, Types, & Rejection | Britannica
transplantation surgery.processed_content: Transplantation surgery involves transferring tissue or organs from one part of the body or from a donor to another site. Organ transplants, like kidney and liver, are complex and require immunosuppression to prevent rejection. The demand for organ transplants often exceeds supply.

trauma surgery.title: At the Ready: A Day in the Life of a Trauma Surgeon
trauma surgery.processed_content: Trauma surgery provides immediate, specialized medical and surgical care for patients experiencing severe, life-threatening injuries from incidents such as accidents, assaults, or burns. This field requires rapid surgical intervention and a coordinated, multidisciplinary team response to treat critical conditions and stabilize patients.

trauma surgery.title: Trauma Surgery: Definition & Procedures | Vaia
trauma surgery.processed_content: Trauma surgery is a specialized branch of surgical medicine dedicated to the rapid treatment and management of severe, critical injuries caused by sudden physical impacts, accidents, or violence. This field is vital in emergency situations, requiring immediate surgical intervention and medical attention to save lives and address life-threatening conditions.

urban planning.title: List of Urban Planning Degree Programs
urban planning.processed_content: Urban planning is an applied social science field that integrates disciplines like geography, economics, and public policy to shape communities. Its primary role is to provide context for community design, considering environmental, historical, and social factors. Urban planners work to address diverse challenges, from transportation and disaster preparedness to housing budgets and civic engagement, focusing on solutions for community development.

urban planning.title: Urban planning of Barcelona - Wikipedia
urban planning.processed_content: Based on the historical account of Barcelona, urban planning involves the strategic design and management of a city's physical environment and public spaces. It adapts to demographic shifts and territorial changes by regulating development, integrating infrastructure, providing essential services, and enhancing living conditions. This process often includes comprehensive plans, specific projects for areas like transport or green spaces, and responses to significant events or challenges. Ultimately, urban planning aims to shape the city's structure and functionality for its inhabitants.

urban planning.title: What is Urban Planning? (with pictures) - Historical Index
urban planning.processed_content: Urban planning is a multidisciplinary practice, rooted in architecture, focused on organizing metropolitan areas. It developed to address problems caused by cities growing spontaneously without foresight. The core aim is to provide a safe, organized, and enjoyable environment for residents by considering factors like building locations, zoning, transportation, appearance, environmental preservation, and the improvement of disadvantaged areas.

urban planning.title: Urban Planning Dictionary: Key Terms and Definitions
urban planning.processed_content: Urban planning is the deliberate organization and design of urban environments focused on sustainable development. This process encompasses the management of land use, transportation networks, housing, and public areas, seeking to harmoniously balance the needs of people, economic activity, and the environment.

urban planning.title: The Role of Urban Planning in Managing Urban Growth
urban planning.processed_content: Urban planning is the discipline concerned with the design and regulation of space within urban areas. Its core aim is to create functional, sustainable, and equitable environments by strategically arranging buildings, infrastructure, and amenities. This process seeks to optimize urban life, manage growth effectively, and often involves collaboration across various fields.

urban planning.title: Urban planning - City Design, Infrastructure, Sustainability | Britannica
urban planning.processed_content: Based on the text, urban planning involves the public regulation and guidance of urban development and land use. It utilizes tools such as master plans, zoning regulations, and subdivision controls to organize city structure, separate incompatible activities, manage building size and density, and facilitate public infrastructure. This process aims to achieve economy and efficiency in the arrangement of the city and guide urban growth, sometimes through the creation of entirely new planned communities.

urban planning.title: What Is Urban Planning Today? - Georgetown SCS
urban planning.processed_content: Urban planning is a practice with deep historical roots that organizes city activities and shapes the built environment to enhance the quality of life for communities. It integrates knowledge from various disciplines such as architecture, economics, sociology, and ecology. Contemporary urban planning aims to foster sustainable, equitable, and resilient urban futures by synthesizing diverse expertise and engaging stakeholders in place-based, community-oriented decision-making.

vascular surgery.title: What a Vascular Surgeon Does
vascular surgery.processed_content: Vascular surgery is a medical specialty dedicated to the diagnosis and treatment of diseases affecting blood vessels throughout the body, excluding those in the heart and brain. Vascular surgeons manage a wide range of vascular conditions using various methods, including medical treatments, minimally invasive procedures, and complex open surgeries. This field addresses issues like blockages, clots, and injuries, providing long-term care for patients with complex vascular health needs.

vascular surgery.title: What is Vascular Surgery? - news.cuanschutz.edu
vascular surgery.processed_content: Vascular surgery treats diseases of the blood vessels using surgical techniques. It includes open and minimally invasive procedures. Common conditions treated are aneurysms, varicose veins, and blockages.

women studies.title: Female education - Wikipedia
women studies.processed_content: Women's studies focuses on women's roles, experiences, and contributions. It examines gender inequality and promotes gender equality. It emerged in the 1970s, combining feminist theory with academic research.

women studies.title: Gender studies - Wikipedia
women studies.processed_content: Gender studies is an interdisciplinary academic field dedicated to analyzing gender identity and representation. Originating from women's studies, it now incorporates perspectives from queer studies and men's studies. The field draws upon various disciplines and examines how gender intersects with other social categories like race, class, and sexuality, often focusing on gender as a social construction distinct from biological sex.

women studies.title: History of women in the United States - Wikipedia
women studies.processed_content: The study of women's history emerged as a significant academic field, particularly in the 1970s, after women's roles were long overlooked in traditional historical accounts. This scholarly discipline involves extensive research, publications, and courses in universities, aiming to understand women's experiences, contributions, and the impact of factors like race, class, and gender throughout history. Academic historians organized to promote this field, creating specialized associations and journals to support scholarship and integrate women's narratives into mainstream historical understanding.

workforce education.title: Promoting Educational Alignment to Workforce Needs
workforce education.processed_content: The text emphasizes the critical need to align educational offerings and training opportunities with the evolving demands of the labor market. It highlights a current misalignment and describes efforts, such as microcredentials and strategic partnerships, aimed at ensuring learners acquire the skills necessary for career advancement and addressing workforce needs. This implies that workforce education, within this context, focuses on bridging the gap between learning and employment requirements.

workforce education.title: Skilled Workforce Education: Latest Trends and Examples
workforce education.processed_content: Workforce education, often referred to as workforce development, encompasses programs, activities, and policies aimed at creating and maintaining a skilled workforce. It involves various training, continuing education, and professional development opportunities designed to equip individuals with the skills required by the evolving labor market. This process is crucial for driving economic prosperity, addressing skills gaps, and preparing workers for future industry demands.

world cultures.title: Ohio's Learning Standards for World Languages and Cultures
world cultures.processed_content: Within world language learning standards, "Cultures" are included to emphasize the importance of developing intercultural communicative competence. This involves understanding and engaging with both one's own culture and global cultures. The standards aim to incorporate intercultural content alongside language skills.

world cultures.title: Understanding the World Languages and Cultures Standards
world cultures.processed_content: In the context of educational standards for language learning, the study of world cultures is integrated to cultivate intercultural skills. This focus helps learners grasp the diverse norms and nuances required for effective communication in authentic global interactions.

world cultures.title: LibGuides: ANTH 102 Cultural Anthropology: Searching Tips
world cultures.processed_content: World cultures encompass diverse traditions, languages, and practices from various ethnic groups globally. Wikipedia offers articles on specific cultures and cultural phenomena. UNESCO promotes the diversity of cultural expressions worldwide.

world cultures.title: List of Indigenous peoples - Wikipedia
world cultures.processed_content: Across the globe, thousands of distinct cultures exist, particularly among Indigenous peoples found on every inhabited continent and climate zone. The text highlights that these groups, spread across diverse geographical regions, possess their own unique languages, cultural patterns, social institutions, and legal systems. This underscores the worldwide diversity of human societies and cultural identities.

world literatures.title: "Teaching World Literatures" by John D. Pizer: Summary and Critique
world literatures.processed_content: The concept of world literature refers to literary works that transcend national, linguistic, and cultural boundaries, often facilitated by translation. While the term itself is considered vague and unstable, suggesting literature from all times and places, it functions both as a pedagogical category and a framework for understanding global literary circulation. Engaging with world literature involves navigating the interplay between universal human themes and specific cultural contexts to expand understanding.

world literatures.title: What Is World Literature? (with pictures) - Language Humanities
world literatures.processed_content: World literature, a concept initially described by Goethe in 1827 regarding the availability of texts from other nations, now refers to literary works from any country with a written language, including ancient texts. Its study involves exploring diverse global writings and cultures. Reading world literature fosters cultural insight, understanding, and the exchange of ideas across borders.

world literatures.title: World literature - Alchetron, The Free Social Encyclopedia
world literatures.processed_content: World literature refers to the global circulation of literary works beyond their countries of origin. It includes masterpieces from various cultures and traditions. The concept emphasizes universal human experiences and aesthetic values.

young adult medicine.title: Adolescent medicine at Inova
young adult medicine.processed_content: Within the field of adolescent medicine, care for young adults extends into early adulthood, often covering individuals up to age 25. This specialized area focuses on addressing their unique physical and emotional health needs and supporting their transition to adult healthcare services. Providers in this field offer comprehensive specialty care tailored to this distinct developmental period.

young adult medicine.title: Care Tailored To Address Physical, Mental Health Needs of Adolescents ...
young adult medicine.processed_content: Young adult medicine is a specialized field focusing on the unique physical and mental health needs of individuals typically aged 12 to 25. It provides developmentally focused care to address the specific challenges faced during adolescence and young adulthood. This type of care manages a range of health concerns, considering the particular developmental and contextual factors relevant to this age group.
